Graphical abstract A hexanuclear Y(III) clusters-based MOFs was successfully synthesized, then the functional Pd(bpydc)Cl2 species were quantitatively incorporated into this material via sequential post-synthetic ligand exchange and metalation. The obtained Pd(II)-Y- bpydcX/bpdc1-X MOFs can be as highly efficient heterogeneous single-site catalysts to promote selective oxidative cleavage of styrene to benzaldehyde using O2 as a green oxidant. Oxidation of styrene is one of the significant reactions in organic synthesis. In this work, a serious of PdCl2 moiety-decorated Y6-MOFs adopting post-synthetic strategy were fabricated as applicable single-site catalysts for oxidation of styrene. Specifically, the functional organic linker, H2bpydc (2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylic acid), was first incorporated quantitatively into Y6 clusters-based MOF, [(CH3)2NH2]2[Y6(μ 3-OH)8(bpdc)6] (bpdc = 4,4′-biphenyl dicarboxylic acid) via post-synthetic ligand exchange. Then post-synthetic Pd(II) metalation was performed to enhance the density of isolated single sites. The obtained Pd(II)-Y-bpydcx/bpdc1-x can be used as highly efficient heterogeneous single-site catalysts to promote selective oxidative cleavage of styrene to benzaldehyde using O2 as a oxidant under solvent-free and mild reaction conditions (1 atm and 80 °C). Importantly, when using Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 (0.024 mmol Pd) as catalyst, the high conversion of styrene and the selectivity for benzaldehyde can reach 88.7 % and 82.2 %, respectively. Keywords Metal-organic framework Y6 clusters Heterogeneous single-site catalysts Oxidation of styrene 1 Introduction Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as a special class of functional porous materials have been studied extensively in recent decades [1–3]. These materials exhibit high surface area, porosity and functional tunability, which are promising for applications in various areas, especially in catalysis [4–7]. MOFs not only combine the advantages of heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts, with high catalytic activity and recyclability, but also have abundant and designable catalytic sites. The MOFs’ inherent metal nodes [8], functional group on the ligand [9] and the guest molecules in the pore are potential catalytic sites [10]. In addition, catalytic species can also be incorporated into the frameworks via post-synthetic modification, such as post-synthetic metalation (PSM) and post-synthetic exchange (PSE) [11–14]. The oxidation of styrene is a very important reaction in the chemical industry since the products of the oxidation, benzaldehyde and epoxides et al., are important and useful intermediates in the production of many pharmaceuticals and fine chemicals [15,16]. In particular, as a versatile chemical raw material, the benzaldehyde is widely used in medicine, agriculture, and fine chemical industry [17–19]. So, the development of highly efficient and selective catalysts for the oxidation cleavage of styrene to benzaldehyde is of vital importance. Many palladium complexes have been found to be active homogeneous catalysts in the oxidation of styrene reaction in decades [20]. However, difficulty in separation of catalyst from reaction mixture, reusing of expensive noble metal and purification of products are still urgent tasks that need to be addressed. In this regard, many efforts have been made to search some supports which are used to support homogeneous palladium species to achieve heterogeneous single-site catalysts. Heterogeneous single-site catalysts are constitutive of isolated, well-defined and active sites that are spatially separated in a given solid materials and, ideally, structurally identical [21]. MOFs' unique, periodic network structure that enables spatial separation of unsaturated metal sites makes them candidates for single-site catalysts [22–24]. Therefore, immobilized palladium species into MOFs via PSM is an effective strategy to afford catalytically active and recyclable material [25–27], and expected to be used as the active sites for the oxidation of styrene to benzaldehyde. Herein, a hexanuclear Y(III) clusters-based MOF, [(CH3)2NH2]2[Y6(μ 3-OH)8(L)6] (L = bpdc (Y-bpdc)), has been constructed by a linear dicarboxylate (H2bpdc = 4,4′-biphenyl dicarboxylic acid) (Fig. 1 ) under solvothermal condition. The resulting Y-bpdc was further functionalized through post-synthetic ligand exchange and Pd(II) metalation process, obtaining the Pd(II) single-site functional MOFs which are highly crystalline and porous show efficient and heterogeneous catalytic activity during the oxidation of styrene to benzaldehyde. In addition, the catalytic activity can be enhanced with the increase of the amount of Pd(II) introducing into the framework within limits. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods All chemicals for synthesis were commercially available reagents of analytical grade and were used without further purification. The C, H and N microanalyses were carried out with Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. N2 adsorption-desorption experiments were carried out on an automated gas sorption analyzer (Quantachrome Instruments ASiQC). The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the 4000−400 cm−1 range on a Nicolet 5DX spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a PerkinElmer Pyrisl instrument (25−800 °C, 5 °C min-1, flowing N2). Powder X-ray diffraction was recorded with a Bruker AXS D8 advanced automated diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation. The products of catalysis reaction are monitored by Gas chromatography with a SP-2100A Gas chromatograph (GC). Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP) was performed using a 700 Series ICPOES (Agilent Technologies). 1H-NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian-300 MHz NMR spectrometer. EDX analysis (Genesis Apollo X/XL EDS) operated at 300 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a Kratos AxisUltra DLD system with a base pressure of 10−9 Torr. 2.2 Preparation of [(CH3)2NH2][Y6(μ3-OH)8(bpdc)6] (Y-bpdc) A mixture of H2bpdc (200 mg, 0.83 mmol), Y(NO3)3·6H2O (360 mg, 0.94 mmol), 2-FBA (3.8 g, 27.32 mmol) were added in 100 mL mixed solvents of DMF (80 mL) and EtOH (20 mL), uniformly utrasonic and evenly divided into scintillation vials. The resulting mixture was kept in an oven at 105 °C for 36 h. After cooling the vials to room temperature, the as-synthesized sample was purified through repeated washings with DMF to yield yellow transparent octahedral crystals. Yield: 55 % (based on the crystals dried in air). Anal. calcd. for C88H72N2O32Y6: C 47.98, H 3.29, N 1.27 %. Found: C 48.02, H 3.33, N 1.26 %. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3403 (br), 1668 (s), 1608 (s), 1537 (w), 1412 (s), 1396 (s), 1251 (w), 1175 (w), 1094 (m), 1006 (w), 864 (w), 803 (w), 772 (s), 707 (w), 672 (w). 2.3 Ligand exchange experiments A mixture of H2bpydc (10 mg) and Y-bpdc (15 mg) were added in 1.5 mL DMF in a 5 mL scintillation vial and mixed uniformly. The resulting mixture was kept in an oven at 75 °C for a while. After cooling the vial to room temperature, the as-synthesized sample was filtered, washed and dried to get hexnuclear yttrium clusters MOFs (Y-bpydcx/bpdc1-x ) with different ligand ratios. The ratio of bpdc and bpydc ligands in MOFs was controlled quantitatively by adjusting the ligand exchange time. Ligand exchange progress was determined by 1H-NMR analysis. After 2 days of ligand exchange, the ligand proportion in the MOFs obtained was bpydc0.2/bpdc0.8, the molecular formula is [(CH3)2NH2]2[Y6(μ 3-OH)8(bpdc)4.8(bpydc)1.2] (Y-bpydc0.2/bpdc0.8 ). After 4 days of ligand exchange, the ligand proportion in the MOFs obtained was bpydc0.5/bpdc0.5, the molecular formula is [(CH3)2NH2]2[Y6(μ 3-OH)8(bpdc)3(bpydc)3] (Y-bpydc0.5/bpdc0.5 ). After 7 days of ligand exchange, the ligand proportion in the MOFs obtained was bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2, the molecular formula is [(CH3)2NH2]2[Y6(μ 3-OH)8(bpdc)1.2(bpydc)4.8] (Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 ). 2.4 Pd (II) metallization experiment 2.4.1 The preparation of PdCl2(CH3CN)2 100 mg PdCl2 was added to a round-bottom flask, which was vacuumed and N2 circulation treatment to remove oxygen in the reaction system. The 40 mL acetonitrile was then injected and heated to 90 °C under the N2. At the end of the reaction, the reaction solution was cooled to room temperature, and the excess solvent was removed by rotary evaporator to obtain yellow powder, which was the target product PdCl2(CH3CN)2 2.4.2 Pd (II) metallization of MOFs 30 mg PdCl2(CH3CN)2 (0.12 mmol) was weighed and added into a 5 mL scintillation vial and dissolved with 2 mL DMF. Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 , Y-bpydc0.5/bpdc0.5 and Y-bpydc0.2/bpdc0.8 (0.02 mmol) were soaked in the above organic Pd solution and placed in the 65 °C oven. The mixture was removed after 3 days of heating, cooled to room temperature, filtered and washed with fresh DMF several times to remove excess organic Pd solution on solid surface until the filtrate is colorless. The solid after washing is soaked in methanol solution. The methanol solvent was changed every day for 3 days. Filtered out the solids after 3 days and dried in a vacuum. 2.5 X-ray crystallography Crystallographic data of Y-bpdc was collected at 100 K with a SuperNova diffractometer equipped with Cu-Kα radiation (λ=1.5418 Å) and graphite monochromator using the ω-scan mode. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least squares using SHELXTL [28]. Non-hydrogen atoms were treated anisotropically. Positions of hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. There is a large solvent accessible pore volume in the structure of Y-bpdc, which is occupied by highly disordered solvent molecules. No satisfactory disorder model for these solvent molecules could be achieved, and therefore the SQUEEZE program implemented in PLATON was used to remove these electron densities of these disordered species [29]. Crystallographic data and experimental details for structural analyses are summarized in Table S4. The CCDC reference numbers 1893342 for Y-bpdc. 2.6 Catalytic performance evaluation Before the catalytic reaction, solvent exchange was treated to remove the residual guest molecules on the surface and in the hole of the sample. After fully drying under vacuum, the catalytic experiment was carried out. The styrene (5.0 mmol) and catalyst (0.005 mmol) were introduced into a reaction tube (10 mL), sealed and bubbled into oxygen under atmospheric pressure. Then reaction mixture was stirred at 80 °C. After 5 h, the reactor was cooled down to room temperature. The catalysts were separated by filtration, and the samples of the reaction mixture were analyzed by GC to determine the conversions. Separated catalyst was washed with methanol and dried under vacuum for reuse. 2.7 Leaching test The catalyst Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 was separated from the reaction system right when the reaction lasted for 2 h, and the reaction was continued in the absence of the catalyst for an additional 3 h. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Crystal structure Single-crystal X-ray crystallography showed that Y-bpdc crystallizes in the cubic space group Fm 3 - m. Each Y(III) ion is eight-coordinated by four μ 3-OH and four distinct carboxylate groups from four independent bpdc2− ligands in a bis-monodentate fashion, showing a square-antiprismatic coordination environment. Six adjacent Y(III) ions are bridged by 8 μ 3-OH and 12 deprotonated carboxylate groups (COO-) in a bis-monodentate fashion to give a hexanuclear Y(III) cluster secondary building unit (SBU), [Y6(μ 3-OH)8(COO)12] (Fig. 2 a), the 12-connected nodes were bridged by bpdc ligands to form a 3D framework with two polyhedral cages, octahedral and tetrahedral (Fig. 2b, c). 3.2 Characterization Accroding to the previously reported literature [30–32], the Pd(II) complexes can exhibit catalytic activity towards the selective oxidative cleavage of styrene to benzaldehyde. So, the functional Pd(II) complexes were quantificationally immobilized into the Y-bpdc by a sequential post-synthetic ligand exchange and metalation process to investigate the correlation between the amount of Pd(II) sites and the catalytic capacity. Post-synthetic ligand exchange of Y-bpdc with H2bpydc ligand (H2bpydc = 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylic acid) was achieved by a directly solvothermal synthesis at 75 °C in DMF for different time. The resulting colorless crystalline solids were separated and washed with DMF and methanol, then dried in air. As shown in FT-IR spectra (Fig. S1), the bpydc linkers with bpy chelating sites were introduced into the framework successfully. The 1H-NMR spectroscopy (Fig. 3 a) upon digestion of these samples with dilute DCl in d 6-DMSO indicated that the ratio of linkers varied according to the reaction time of post-synthetic ligand exchange. As the reaction time increases, the ratio of bpydc linker linear increases, but once the crystal contains ∼80 % bpydc, no further exchange occurs, suggesting that there is an upper limit for bpydc exchange. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) confirmed that the series of obtained crystal samples, Y-bpydcX/bpdc1-X (0 ≤ x ≤ 1, x indicating the amount of bpydc incorporation) are isomorphous and maintain high crystallinity (Fig. 3b). Post-synthetic metalation was performed by treating Y-bpydcX/bpdc1-X with 6.0 equiv of PdCl2(CH3CN)2 in DMF at 65 °C to afford Pd(II)-Y-bpydcx/bpdc1-x as a brown solid. The crystallinity of samples were maintained upon metalation, as evidenced by similar PXRD patterns of Y-bpydcx/bpdc1-x and Y-bpdc. As shown in Fig. 3b, the PXRD patterns of Pd(II)-metalated Y-bpydcx/bpdc1-x are good agreement with that of pristine framework, indicating that the crystallinity of these Y-bpydcx/bpdc1-x are well maintained after the PdCl2 moiety doping. In the case of Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 , variable-temperature PXRD and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) proved that the Pd(II) metalation of Y-bpydcx/bpdc1-x still had good thermal stability, reaching 350 °C (Figs. S2 and S3). To confirm that the PdCl2 moieties were installed onto bpy chelating sites of bpydc ligands and to determine their coordination environment within the framework, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis were performed on Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 and Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 . As shown in Fig. 3c, the appearance of Pd 3d and Cl 2p peaks confirmed the successful immobilization of PdCl2 moieties on the framework, and the binding energies for Pd 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 are 338 and 343 eV, respectively, indicating that the palladium oxidation state of metallized Y-bpydcx/bpdc1-x is bivalent. The N 1s spectra of Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 and Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 (Fig. 3d) show that with the Pd(II) doping in, the N 1s peak appears to shift to a higher binding energy, indicating the coordination between N atom of bpydc group and the Pd(II) site. Moreover, the absence of multiple features in the N 1s spectrum of the Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 seems to further verify the presence of only one environment for N, namely each Pd(II) is bonded to the uncoordinated bpy group. The energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) showed 1:(0.16 ± 0.02):(0.4 ± 0.05), 1:(0.49 ± 0.02):(1.00 ± 0.05) and 1:(0.80 ± 0.04):(1.80 ± 0.06) atomic ratio of Y:Pd:Cl in Pd(II)-Y-bpydcx/bpdc1-x , respectively (Table S1), indicating that all the bpydc sites incorporated in these samples are nearly quantitative Pd(II) metallized. Moreover, the doped Pd(II) amount (1.0 wt %) were also confirmed by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis, and the ratio of Y:Pd in Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.2/bpdc0.8 is 1:0.16, Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.5/bpdc0.5 is 1:0.49 and Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 is 1:0.79 (Table S2), which are correspond to the EDS analysis. Therefore, the corresponding formula of these Pd(II)-doping samples can be given as Y6(μ 3−OH)8(bpydcPdCl2)3(bpdc)3 (Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.2/bpdc0.8 ), Y6(μ 3−OH)8(bpydcPdCl2)3(bpdc)3 (Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.5/bpdc0.5 ) and Y6(μ 3−OH)8(bpydcPdCl2)4.8(bpdc)1.2 (Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 ), respectively. It can be inferred from the N2 adsorption experiment of Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 and Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 at 77 K that all of the Y-bpdcx/bpydc1-x and Pd(II) doping samples display a fully reversible Type-I isotherm through the investigation of N2 adsorption at 77 K (Fig. S4), confirming that the microporosity of these Y6-MOF is maintained after post-synthetic ligand exchange and Pd(II)-metalation. Y-bpdc and Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 exhibit similar Brunauer-Emmett Teller (BET) surface areas (1256.55 m² g–1 and 1299.64 m² g–1) and pore volumes (0.48 cm3 g–1 and 0.55 cm3 g–1). However, with the PdCl2 moieties doping in, both of the BET surface areas and pore volumes of the framework are decreased obviously due to the steric-hinerance effect. The BET surface areas and experimental pore volumes of Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 were estimated to 275.73 m² g–1 and 0.096 cm3 g–1, respectively (Table S3). 3.3 Catalytic oxidation of styrene As an important industrial transformation process [33–35], the oxidation of styrene was chosen to demonstrate the catalytic capacity of these Pd(II)-containing catalysts, which was carried out using O2 as a oxidant under solvent-free and mild reaction conditions. The product of oxidation of styrene is diversity, such as benzaldehyde, styrene oxide, benzoic acid, etc., among which the benzaldehyde (a) and styrene oxide (b) are the main products, and the former is our target product. The conversion and selectivity for the oxidation of styrene on Y6-MOF and Pd(II)-Y6-MOFs were confirmed by gas chromatography (GC) analyses and summarized in Table 1 . Firstly, when the reaction was carried out without catalyst, no styrene conversion was observed (Table 1, entry 1). Then, the catalytic activities of Y6-MOFs with different Pd(II) loading amounts, Pd(II)-Y-bpydcx/bpdc1-x , were investigated and the results were shown in Table 1. Thereinto, the Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 exhibit higher catalytic activity. After 5 h, the conversion of styrene and the selectivity for benzaldehyde using Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 (0.024 mmol Pd) as catalyst can reach 88.7 % and 82.2 % (Table 1, entry 5), respectively, which outperform some MOF-based catalysts. Under the similar reaction condition, MOF-74(Co) [36] selectivity (35 %) using approximate 3.5 times amount of catalyst (0.34 mol%) (Table 1, entry 10). Under a non-green reaction condition, MIL-MOFs [37] demonstrated inferior catalytic activity for oxidation of styrene to benzaldehyde (entries 11–12). For the Cr-MIL-101 [38] (Table 1, entry 13), the benzaldehyde selectivity exceeded 90 %, but the conversion was just 46.79 %. TSHM crystals can also give styrene a higher conversion of ca. 90 %, but need extend reaction times (12 h) and more powerful oxidant (TBHP), moreover, its benzaldehyde selectivity was just ca. 60 %, lower than the Pd(II)-loading Y-bpydcx/bpdc1-x (Table 1, entry 14). The conversion of Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.5/bpdc0.5 (0.015 mmol Pd) and Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.2/bpdc0.8 (0.006 mmol Pd) were 61.9 % and 45.0 %, the selectivity were 85.9 % and 90.1 %, respectively. An obvious decline in the conversion of styrene can be noticed with the amount of Pd(II) sites in the framework decreasing, however, the selectivity of benzaldehyde exhibit trends of increase (Table 1, entries 6–7). So, this Pd(II)-Y-bpydcx/bpdc1-x MOFs exhibit tunable catalytic properties for aerobic selective oxidation of styrene via modulation of the Pd(II) amount incorporated into the framework. Temperature has always been an important factor affecting catalytic reactions. Therefore, a model reaction, with 5 mmol styrene, Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 (0.005 mmol, 0.1 mol%), 1 atm O2 and 5 h, were performed to explore the effect of temperature on the oxidation of styrene. As shown in the Fig. S5, the conversion increased significantly as the temperature increases from 25 °C to 120 °C. However, when the temperature reached 80 °C, the selectivity reached an inflection point and reaches its maximum. Thus, the best reaction temperature was 80 °C. In comparison, Y-bpdc (Table 1, entry 2) and Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 (Table 1, entry 4) were also tested. Under the same condition, these two materials show no catalytic activity. When the reaction time extended to 12 h, the conversion of styrene just reached 50.1 % and 85 % selectivity for benzaldehyde (Table 1, entry 6), further indicating that the introduction of Pd(II) can significantly improve the catalytic activity of the Y6-MOF, in other words, the Pd(bpydc)Cl2 species immobilized in the framework play an important role in the catalytic performance. PdCl2 (0.024 mmol) as a homogeneous catalyst for the oxidation of styrene was also tested, which gave lower conversion of styrene (54.3 %) and yield of benzaldehyde (78.0 %) under the same reaction condition. After 7 h, the conversion increased to ca. 90 %, but a reduction of benzaldehyde selectivity occur (64.8 %). To study the general applicability of the catalyst, some aryl- and alkyl- substituted terminal olefins were investigated and the experimental results were summarized in Table 2 . As observed from Table 2, conversion and selectivity of the aromatic terminal olefins with electron-withdrawing and electron-donating substituted groups were 63.3–81.6 % and 75.1–80.3 % (Table 2, entries 1–3), respectively. However, for aliphatic alkene 1-octene, the catalytic effect is relatively poor. Although the selectivity of the product heptanal was 77.7 %, only 29.1 % conversion was obtained (Table 2, entry 4). According to the above experimental results, the proposed reaction mechanism was inferred in Fig. S6. Firstly, activation of oxygen by the Pd(II) leads to an Pd-superoxo radical, and the olefin substrates bond to the Pd(II). Next, the superoxo radical is proposed to undergo radical cyclization with the coordinated olefin, affording a five-membered peroxometallacycle. The latter collapses via reductive elimination to give the dioxetane, which is expected to decompose readily to afford benzaldehyde and styrene epoxide. In addition, benzoic acid may be formed by the deep oxidation of benzaldehyde [40,41]. To investigate recyclability and reusability of Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 , the recovery experiments were examined under same reaction conditions as mentioned earlier. After three runs of reactions, Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 still remained highly active (Fig. 4 a). The PXRD showed that the structure of the single-site catalyst remained stable during the catalytic process and was not affected by the reaction system (Fig. S7). Additionally, ICP-MS analyses showed that the amounts of Pd(II) in the skeleton of the catalyst did not change significantly before and after the catalytic reaction (Table S2). Moreover, no further conversion was detected after removal of Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 during the course of the oxidation of styrene reaction (Fig. 4b). 4 Conclusion In summary, we employed a post-synthetic strategy, including post-synthetic ligand exchange and metalation operation, to synthesize a series of PdCl2 moiety-decorated Y6-MOFs. These materials contain high densities of isolated, single active Pd(II) sites and exhibit excellent conversion and selectivity towards the aerobic oxidation of styrene to benzaldehyde. More remarkably, their catalytic capacity is tunable via the regulation of Pd(II) amount. Herein, linker engineering strategy is an effective approach to synthesize single-site catalysts with tunable catalytic property and can also be extended to other catalytic system. coredata.dc:description: Oxidation of styrene is one of the significant reactions in organic synthesis. In this work, a serious of PdCl2 moiety-decorated Y6-MOFs adopting post-synthetic strategy were fabricated as applicable single-site catalysts for oxidation of styrene. Specifically, the functional organic linker, H2bpydc (2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylic acid), was first incorporated quantitatively into Y6 clusters-based MOF, [(CH3)2NH2]2[Y6(μ 3-OH)8(bpdc)6] (bpdc = 4,4′-biphenyl dicarboxylic acid) via post-synthetic ligand exchange. Then post-synthetic Pd(II) metalation was performed to enhance the density of isolated single sites. The obtained Pd(II)-Y-bpydcx/bpdc1-x can be used as highly efficient heterogeneous single-site catalysts to promote selective oxidative cleavage of styrene to benzaldehyde using O2 as a oxidant under solvent-free and mild reaction conditions (1 atm and 80 °C). Importantly, when using Pd(II)-Y-bpydc0.8/bpdc0.2 (0.024 mmol Pd) as catalyst, the high conversion of styrene and the selectivity for benzaldehyde can reach 88.7 % and 82.2 %, respectively.
coredata.dc:title: Functional hexanuclear Y(III) cluster-based MOFs supported Pd(II) single site catalysts for aerobic selective oxidation of styrene
